metadata.name: Fibril #340
metadata.description:
real-time webGL fabric simulation. 

p - play/pause
r - reset to initial state
s - export plottable svg
i - zoom in
o - zoom out

WebGL 2.0 support required.

metadata.name: PIPES #123
metadata.description:
PIPES are its own creatures growing out of an Octree, swirling and twirling towards each's individual destination.  

Features:   
  There are four different flow modes, seven different palettes.   
  PIPES can either be hollow or filled, and there is a small chance the PIPES is drawn in gradient.  

Loading time is about 6s and then it will start to animate. Thank you for your patience.  

Press 'S' to save a high resolution 4800x4800px PNG of the artwork.  

This work is made purely with p5js.

metadata.name: alchemy(maxima) #90
metadata.description:
This collection takes its main inspiration from the Turkish marbling art “Ebru” and tries to spin it with a golden twist, hence alchemy :) 

alchemy(maxima) tries to create a composition either using one of the two grid types, and sometimes breaking them or in a totally chaotic way, but uses color harmony and rhythm to keep the chaos in check and the resulting image still somewhat interesting and sometimes golden-ish…

The name includes “maxima” because this is the first part of a 2-part series; its companion collection “alchemy(minima)” will be released soon and as per my tradition will be freely available to maxima holders.

From the proceeds of the primary sales of alchemy(maxima),

- 33% will directly go to The Processing Foundation,
- 33% will fund the greater evil,
- 34% will be used to grow my collection.

So in a way, all the proceeds will go back into the ecosystem. This is my way of making up for taking tez out with my donations earlier.

If you are wondering what the hell “the greater evil” is, read about it here : 

https://twitter.com/evilnft/status/1544320804304961536?s=20&t=AoEfLfn32tGNR8JTi5Jjng

And find it here:

https://www.fxhash.xyz/u/the%20greater%20evil/collection

—

About the work: 

- 22 palettes - 7 new, 15 recycled,
- 3 main variants,
- 4 sub-variants each,
- 9 visible and some hidden features :)
- After going live, press “s” to save a png (at your screen resolution)
- No hi-res output due to the warp manipulating the pixel array directly, which means higher res equals to much higher computation time.

Thank you all in advance and have a good day!

Warp functions are based on this article by Inigo Quilez : https://iquilezles.org/articles/warp/

DISCLAIMER : I am not a good coder, I have tried to fix my past mistakes from my earlier projects to make some room for new mistakes :) I am learning on the way and certainly hoping that there aren't any huge bugs or anything, so you can enjoy your mint! Please hit me up if you have any concerns after minting and we can discuss a solution.

metadata.name: Zhu(竹) #43
metadata.description:
Zhu(竹):

"Zhu" is a series of 100 oriental abstract pieces featuring the imagery of bamboo, a symbol of integrity and strength in traditional Chinese culture.

Zhu's generative system is an exploration of this cultural symbol by modern art language. Elements of the paintings are merely circles, enclosed flow field shapes, and the blank space behind these visual objects. Blank-leaving is intentionally applied at various degrees throughout the series. The vast empty space beyond the plants is open to and embraces every kind of interpretation.

Zhu's outputs span hours of the day from dawn to dusk to night. Its color schemes explored four styles from traditional to modern. The simple yet complex senses and feelings reflected are surprisingly versatile.

metadata.name: Cuts #31
metadata.description:
Cuts is an abstract representation of the exact moments in our lives when something is cut. It could be moving to a different country, being fired, quitting a bad habit, when a relationship ends or when you receive a very bad (or good!) news.
By themselves, cuts are not positive or negative events; it really depends on who you were before and who you wish to be after. But one thing is sure: every cut creates a new space that wasn’t there. This space could be small or huge, ordered or chaotic, regardless, you have to deal with it. Sometimes cuts try to resist and heal themselves extruding the core of the fibres we are made of, but they will fail. A cut is irreversible and it’s up to us to fill the gap with meaning.

Main features include:
- Curated palettes (21)
- Drawing modes (3)
- Extrusions (yes/no)
- Orientation (3)
- Overlapping (yes/no)
- Covered area (2)
- Cut position (2)

In live mode:
- Press [s] to save a 2400x2400 px image
- Press [t] to toggle shading (sometimes flat colours rock!)
- Press [c] to see copyright notice
- Press [f] to log features in console

By Todemashi 2022
NFT License 2.0

### NOTES
Made with p5js and GLSL shaders.
Shaders are based on tutorials and code by Patricio Gonzalez Vivo - The Book of Shaders - https://thebookofshaders.com/

metadata.name: Proxima #18
metadata.description:
The preparations for the first mission began in 2142. It had become clear that mining petroleum on Earth would soon become financially unfeasible, so looking to other planets was the only logical choice. It took seventeen more years to perfect the technology so that the first colonists could reach Proxima b within the lifetime of one generation.

After 45 years of travelling at almost one-tenth of the speed of light, they reached their new home. It was rich in petrochemicals but scarce in the nutrients necessary for long term human survival. After merely six generations, humanity was forced to travel once again in search of a new world. The four missions that parted from the Proxima system to colonise other possibly habitable planets in the galaxy sparked a new age of human civilisation that would never see itself united and thriving again.

Eventually, all the colonies became independent societies as their differing interests drove them apart. Each small civilisation chose its path, wandering the void of space alone. Over time, millions of kilometres apart, each colony developed its own culture and traditions. While their habits and customs changed, some things remained the same across all the societies, like how it became a certain tradition to convert the outer world years and days to Earth time and celebrate holidays according to the calendar of the old world.

The new nomads learned from the first pilgrims. They used the technology once optimised for oil extraction to traverse other worlds, searching for sustenance. Peculiar wandering nonspaces emerged from the involuntary degrowth of human civilisation.

-----

Click on the image to open the menu. You may choose the quality from preview to the resolution of a print of approximately 30cm in height. In live mode, click on PNG to save the rendered image.
Depending on the device and CPU usage, it takes from a few seconds (on fast computers) to a minute (sometimes more) on mid-tier phones to render the image.

Requirements: 1GB of RAM. The system needs up to 200 MB of free RAM for rendering square preview images and up to 400 MB of free RAM for rendering square images at the highest resolution. We tested on Chrome, Safari, Firefox, Edge / Windows, Mac OS, Android, and iPhone, but please make sure it works on your device before minting.

Original piece by mrkswcz and Ismahelio. Made with Three.js. 

San Sebastian - Madrid. May 2022.

attributes.name: world
attributes.value: Gliese 667 Cc. A colourless land under the burgundy light of a red dwarf in a triple-star system.

attributes.name: culture
attributes.value: Hovering. This society perfected the technique of creating structures that allow them to linger above the ground.

attributes.name: community size
attributes.value: A medium-size colony, most similar to today's concept of a city.

attributes.name: festive colors
attributes.value: Classic ruby reminder of the degrowth of the predecessors.

metadata.name: C-SCAPE #168
metadata.description:
Cellular Automata are one of the oldest and simplest classes of generative systems. Beginning with the highly abstracted, reductionist models of artificial life research by Stanislav Ulam and John von Neumann in the 1940s, Barricelli in the early 1950s, then re-discovered, formalized, expanded and popularized by other mathematicians like Conway and Wolfram 20-30 years later, it's a long-running field of research, rich with unexpected surprises and new discoveries. C-SCAPE is (a partial) result of over 20 years of my own explorations and a celebration of these simple systems.

Most of my purely generative work has been about creating and harnessing emergent complexity & nonrepetitve, ever-changing behaviors (and their interactions) borne from extremely simple systems, mechanisms, algorithms & languages: Exposing, investigating (and yes, celebrating) generativity in its raw form. By minimizing, though not entirely avoiding, additional human aesthetic decision making (here primarily in the form of curating automata rules & color themes), I'm trying to focus the observer on the raw beauty of the underlying processes and bring it to the fore. My hope is, this too will lead viewers asking themselves the deeper questions about the nature of rules, behavior, order and complexity in their own lives, esp. in the current rising polarizing political & anti-science climate. Furthermore, I'd like to provide a counter point and emphasize the unique qualities of generative art, compared to other, more figurative and abstract art approaches.

C-SCAPE simulates a shared toroidal environment in which multiple cellular automata (CA) are evolving and influencing each other, forming short-lived symbioses and/or wiping each other out, only to be restored again later on. The automata are all operating on a single row of pixels at a time and therefore are only 1-dimensional. Yet, many of them also have a short term memory and can produce more complex structures/behaviors by utilizing their memory of previous cell states. Each individually minted version produces a unique system which evolves over time and never repeats.

The final selection of CA rules used in this piece is the result of many years of experimentation with 100,000s of different configurations and many (manual) review/pruning/cataloging sessions to encourage the minted editions to cover a interesting & balanced subset of the more than duodecillion (10^39) possible individual structures & textures (not including interactions and/or color variations)...

Viewing

The piece in best viewed in medium/high resolution landscape format. The horizontal resolution should be at the very least 800 pixels, preferably double that or higher. There's a max. pixel resolution limit of 4096 pixels in either direction, but CPU performance might suffer at these resolutions. On narrow/mobile portrait ratios the piece will be shown 90 degrees rotated and is scrolling sideways.

Controls

- x : export current frame
- r : randomize environment

License

https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/

Disclaimer

Minting this project will not guarantee inclusion in access lists for future projects.

Credits

Made in 2022 with <3 and thi.ng

metadata.name: Perpetual Oscillations  #73
metadata.description:
Planes expand and contract over time in different rhythms. 

Display notes:
The work is intended to be viewed running live in the browser, and there is no set aspect ratio. The viewer is invited to explore the space and choose their viewpoint. 

Controls:
Left-clicking and dragging - rotate around the center 
right-clicking and dragging - pan around the space 
Scrolling - zoom in and out 
Press b - b-side 
Press o - go back to the origin 
Press 1 to 3 - change the pixel density
Adjusting pixel density or changing the screen size will bring you back to the origin. 

License: CC BY-NC-ND 4.0

Made with p5.js

metadata.name: Modern Times #146
metadata.description:
Created by Eko33, a generative artist featured at the Tezos Ecosystem Exhibition (Art Basel Miami 2021).

This generative artwork creates a limited series of distinctive artworks based on unique hash seeds.

The algorithmic approach of this collection generates a broad spectrum of unique outcomes, inspired by the "giant machine" from the movie "Modern Times."

Beyond a classic mechanical representation, Eko33 aims to convey multiple emotions while embracing the cold nature of algorithms.

Computer-generated generative art can be seen as a gigantic assembly line. Still, its true nature gives the artist complete freedom from all commercially available tools/constraints.

The collection "Modern Times" highlights the dark ages of generative arts using a bichromatic color palette and evolves toward the contemporary "Digital Renaissance" era using warmer, more acid and "pop" colors.

About Eko33:
Official fx(hash) page: https://www.fxhash.xyz/u/Eko33
Official Website: https://www.eko33.com/

metadata.name: AI Humans #7
metadata.description:
AI Humans

The ability to integrate the use of AI into my work in some capacity is something that has been circling around my head for quite some time.

The first exploration is AI Humans; for this collection, I used Stable Diffusion to create more than 200 different faces, with different traits, and different styles.  Then those results were curated by a face recognition algorithm with some changed arguments in order to create some dystopian results.

The final countdown was 50 faces, then each face was separated into three layers

Top (cranium)
Features (eyes, nose, accessories)
Upper body (Neck & chin)

Once the layers were done, I ran the first generative test to discard possible errors, mostly layer positioning. Once these errors were corrected I ran a second and final version with amazing results.

Usually, the naming of the layers is referred to as the visual description of the trait, but in this case, I wanted to be something less human and more machine. For that matter, the layers are named with random numbers assigned by an algorithm. In the end, we all are just random numbers.

Some matches are not perfect and that is the idea. AI is not perfect (yet), and humans are not perfect either, but the results are really intriguing, the mix of features and styles is what makes our imagination fly. 

Licensing
Each AI Human is CC0, so feel free to use it as you see fit

Made with love, AI & pj5s

By CodeNFT (Clementine Novak)
September 2022

metadata.name: GM.GEN.MATH #227
metadata.description:
Released on the occasion of the Tribute to Herbert W. Franke.
100% of the proceeds from primary sales are donated to the Foundation Herbert W. Franke. 
https://www.tribute-hwf.com/

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Undisputably, my mathematical background makes me naturally attracted to graphs, math functions, and transformations. I use math in ways that mathematicians could consider nonsense, but which produce fascinating aesthetic elements for creation (to paraphrase Herbert W. Franke). Combining scientific symbols and illustrations with fictional data produces pseudo-persuasive generative imagery that we can easily take to be absolute truth or in which we find meaningful patterns.
In the special issue of Leonardo, Visual Mathematics from 1992, Herbert W. Franke and Horst S. Helbig published the article Generative Mathematics: Mathematically Described and Calculated Visual Art.

They propose that “Through the use of [mathematical] formulas (software) we gain generative principles. Beyond formal descriptions, we obtain guides for the construction of images. For example, if we use a parametric representation of a curve, the result is similar to traditional methods of drawing and painting […]“ Additionally, mathematics removes frame limits and adds the possibilities for transitions, transformations, movement, and interaction by implementing simple changes to the defining parameters.

I’m also very fond of the analysis and comparison (mentioned there) of digitally generated images and Constructivist design. Limitations of the technology (in the 70s) allowed only simple line drawings, based on fixed proportions same as Constructivists did. “In a short time, all possible features were exhausted, so it became an obvious goal to try to extend them. This was done first by the use of random generators — a highly interesting expansion of design principles […]” Another expansion happened by adding curved shapes, first simple then complex that overcame possibilities of drawing with compasses and rulers. “[…] oscillating curves are easily obtained through mathematical formulas and computer-graphic systems. The results we achieve on this basis do not look like Constructivist presentations, but their rationality and precision derive from Constructivist principles. ”

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Each mint contains both dark and light version, use D/N keys to switch between “day & night”.
 
Base shapes are circles or Lissajous curves modified by the noise function. Shapes are arranged in a grid or by a circle packing algorithm. Lines are drawn smoothly or in stripes. Around 20% of the mints have lines in only one color (black/white). 

Depending on the browser/configuration rendering times will vary.

metadata.name: COMPUTERS #19
metadata.description:
Generative animated painting made from pixel array computations and classic noise algorithms.

COMPUTERS is a meditation on the aesthetics of computing in all of its forms. It recalls the types of computation required to build temples, write complex texts, weave detailed textiles, and program computer games. Pixels have always existed in some form or another, before and after the screen. Every iteration of COMPUTERS suggests that computation is both contemporary and ancient.

Press 'p' or click to pause the animation.
Press 's' to capture a single frame.
Made with P5.js and GLSL. By @galoandstuff.

metadata.name: Millefoglie #419
metadata.description:
"A mille-feuille (French pronunciation: ​[mil fœj], "thousand-sheets"), also known by the names Napoleon, vanilla slice, and custard slice, is a dessert made of puff pastry layered with pastry cream. Its modern form was influenced by improvements made by Marie-Antoine Carême.

Traditionally, a mille-feuille is made up of three layers of puff pastry (pâte feuilletée), alternating with two layers of pastry cream (crème pâtissière). The top pastry layer is finished in various ways: sometimes it is topped with whipped cream, or it may be dusted with icing sugar, cocoa, pastry crumbs, or sliced almonds. It may also be glazed with icing or fondant alone, or in alternating white (icing) and brown (chocolate) or other colored icing stripes, and combed to create a marbled effect." — Wikipedia

Prints available upon request: prints@stefancontiero.com
Best enjoyed on browsers supporting Display-P3 color gamut.

License: CC BY-NC-ND 4.0

@stefan_contiero

metadata.name: Miniscapes #385
metadata.description:
Miniscapes merges generative code (Rich's bit) with meticulously designed scenes and elements (Rick's bit), to create minimalist landscapes intended to charm, delight, and surprise.

Our aim was to convey as much as possible with as little as possible by using simple shapes and lines to represent a wide variety of natural landscapes.

We hope that you find as much joy in owning a Miniscape as we did in creating them.

Controls (in live view):
- Press [s] to save the current image
- Press [p] to pause an animated output
- Press [r] to reset an animated output (this will also pause)
